message: Where do you see node?
https://github.com/brunch/brunch
npm install brunch, in the readme
Ah, npm is just a generic package manager
I don't see how using node would have any impact on it
brunch doesn't rely on node
http://brunchwithcoffee.com/  It's a front-end framework
It does seem pretty cool though, I've been meaning to play around with backbone for a while
Where do you see the reliance on express?

It does depend on node. Express is a web framework that runs on top of node. npm is a package manager for node, and also depends on it. The automatic build process runs on node, as does the web server.
one option is to start an express site
it has a build process like those for static sites, where it builds templates and css
well, I was writing what I thought was the most common use-case
The express server is just a for testing :)
holy spanglish batman! ;)
I think I would classify it as a development dependency

The default project relies on express, unless you explicitly tell it to make it a static site. All of the handy tools that compile your SASS and CoffeeScript all need that express server too. Without node, the usefulness of brunch shrinks dramatically.
see, that's because you think you need node
brunch is awesome because it assembles a bunch of libraries that make pure client development super compelling
yeah - it's gorgeous

Pros
Why this system
rocks more than others
The only real problem with it is it's not kept up to date, so doesn't have the latest packages, but the project layout seems like a good thing to emulate
how are backbone.js, coffeescript, eco, underscore, and zepto not an amazing way to build html/js apps?
express is the weakest link in that entire lineup

If you want to have a node base project have a look at https://github.com/robrighter/node-boilerplate. It uses LESS instead of SASS for CSS, and comes with web sockets support out of the box (not to mention, it's based on @paul_irish's excellent HTML5 Boilerplate)
gave it a shot. really digging it.
